question_details.query: Which interventions can increase invertebrate abundance on subtidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One of two replicated, controlled studies in Israel and off Sweden found that creating hole habitats on subtidal artificial structures increased the abundance of brown crabs, but not other mobile invertebrates (3434). Another study reported that creating holes along with pits, grooves and environmentally-sensitive material had mixed effects on invertebrate abundances, depending on the species group (3434). One replicated, randomized, controlled study in Italy found that creating textured surfaces on subtidal artificial structures had mixed effects on the non-mobile invertebrate abundance on structure surfaces, depending on the site (3449). Three randomized, controlled studies in Australia and France found that creating short flexible habitats on subtidal artificial structures had mixed effects on the mobile and/or non-mobile invertebrate abundance on and around structure surfaces, depending on the survey week, species group, flexible habitat length, or site (3450). One of the studies found no effect on mobile invertebrate abundance (3450).

question_details.query: What are the benefits of creating rock pools on intertidal artificial structures for overall species richness?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Nine of twelve replicated, controlled studies found that rock pools created on intertidal artificial structures supported higher combined macroalgae, invertebrate and/or fish species diversity and/or richness than structure surfaces without pools (3476). Three replicated, controlled studies found that creating hole habitats on intertidal artificial structures, along with rock pools, or grooves, small protrusions and environmentally-sensitive material, increased the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species diversity and/or richness on structure surfaces (3467). One before-and-after study reported that creating pools, along with reducing the slope of a structure, increased the combined macroalgae, invertebrate and fish species richness on the structure (3476). In contrast, three studies reported similar combined macroalgae and invertebrate or combined mobile invertebrate and fish species richness in pools and on structure surfaces (3476). One study found that combined macroalgae, invertebrate and fish species richness in created pools was similar to natural rock pools, while another reported lower combined mobile invertebrate and fish species richness in created pools (3476). Created rock pools and holes were found to support macroalgae, mobile invertebrate, non-mobile invertebrate and/or fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without these features (3476, 3467). Several factors were studied, with two studies finding the shore level of pools did not affect species richness, while three other studies found pool depth had no effect (3476). However, one study found higher richness in tilted pools than horizontal ones (3476).

question_details.query: What are the general effects on biodiversity of creating linear depressions or elevations on intertidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One replicated, randomized, controlled study in Australia reported that large protrusions created on an intertidal artificial structure supported mobile and non-mobile invertebrate species that were absent from structure surfaces without protrusions (3463). Two replicated, controlled studies in the UK and Australia found that creating large protrusions on an intertidal artificial structure, along with large ridges in one study, did not increase the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness on structure surfaces (3463). One replicated, controlled study in the UK found that creating large protrusions on an intertidal artificial structure, along with large ridges, increased limpet but not barnacle abundance on structure surfaces (3463). One of two replicated, controlled studies in the USA and the UK reported that creating large ledges on intertidal artificial structures, along with grooves and small protrusions, increased the combined macroalgae, microalgae and invertebrate species diversity on structure surfaces (3465). One study found that creating large ridges, along with large protrusions, did not increase the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness (3465). One replicated, randomized, controlled study in the USA reported that creating large ledges on intertidal artificial structures, along with grooves and small protrusions, increased the combined macroalgae, microalgae and invertebrate abundance on structure surfaces (3465).

question_details.query: Which interventions are most consistently effective at altering the overall community composition on subtidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One of two replicated, randomized, controlled studies in Israel and the UK found that creating groove habitats and small ledges on a subtidal artificial structure, along with holes and environmentally-sensitive material, altered the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition on structure surfaces (3452). They also supported non-mobile invertebrate species that were absent from structure surfaces without added habitat features (3452). One study found that creating grooves and small protrusions had mixed effects on the community composition, depending on the orientation of structure surfaces (3452). Two replicated, randomized, controlled studies in Australia and France found that creating short flexible habitats on subtidal artificial structures had mixed effects on the mobile and/or non-mobile invertebrate community composition, depending on the density or length of flexible habitats and/or the site (3450). One of the studies found it altered the non-mobile invertebrate community composition (3450). One replicated, paired sites, controlled study in the USA found that reducing the frequency of cleaning on subtidal artificial structures did not alter the combined invertebrate and fish community composition on and around structure surfaces (3447).

question_details.query: For intertidal artificial structures in Australia, which habitat modifications have shown mixed or neutral results for fish abundance?

summary_details.relevant_summary: A study in an estuary in southeast Australia indicated that creating short flexible habitats (1–50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures did not lead to an increase in fish abundance on and around the structure surfaces during high tide (3459).

question_details.query: Which interventions have been shown to benefit fish populations on subtidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of creating large protrusions (>50 mm), large ridges or ledges (>50 mm), or small ridges or ledges (1–50 mm) on subtidal artificial structures on the biodiversity of those structures (3443, 3445, 3444).

question_details.query: What conservation actions for artificial structures have been studied in estuaries in Australia, and what were the outcomes?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Studies in estuaries in southeast Australia have examined several conservation actions for artificial structures. 

Reducing the slope of intertidal artificial structures, in one study, increased the combined macroalgae, invertebrate and fish species richness when combined with creating rock pools, but another study found it did not increase macroalgal, oyster or mobile invertebrate abundance (3461). Creating long flexible habitats (>50 mm) on subtidal artificial structures supported macroalgae, non-mobile invertebrate and fish species that were not present on surfaces without these habitats, but the effects on fish species richness and the abundance of invertebrates and fish were mixed (3451). Transplanting oysters onto intertidal artificial structures supported macroalgae, mobile invertebrate, non-mobile invertebrate, and fish species that were absent from surfaces without them, and in one study, increased mobile invertebrate species richness. However, other studies found mixed effects on combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and abundance, and no increase in fish species richness or abundance (3472). The creation of short flexible habitats (1-50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures was found in one study to decrease the combined macroalgae, invertebrate and fish species richness, and had mixed effects on the abundance of different species (3459). Lastly, creating pit habitats (1-50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures was found to alter the macroalgae and invertebrate community composition, and in one study that also included grooves, altered the fish community and supported species absent from surfaces without these additions (3475).

question_details.query: What are the general effects of creating linear habitat features, such as grooves, ridges or ledges, on intertidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Creating grooves and small ridges or ledges (1–50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures has been found in some studies to alter the composition of the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community, and to support species that were not present on surfaces without these features (3474). Some studies found that these features increased the diversity and richness of species, while others found mixed effects depending on factors like the site, shore level, and the size and arrangement of the features (3474). In terms of abundance, some studies showed an increase in the combined macroalgae and invertebrate abundance, while others found no increase or mixed effects (3474). For fish, creating these grooves and ledges did not increase species richness or abundance in most studies, but did increase the time benthic fishes spent interacting with the surfaces (3474).

When considering small ridges or ledges (1–50 mm) on their own, some studies found they did not alter the community composition or increase species richness, and they supported lower species richness and abundance of mobile invertebrates and oysters compared to the grooves between them (3464).

Creating just groove habitats (1–50 mm) has shown mixed results. While some studies found no change in the overall community composition, one noted that grooves supported species not found on unmodified surfaces (3473). Some studies found an increase in overall species richness and diversity, while others did not (3473). Grooves were found to support higher species richness than the ridges or ledges between them (3473). Fish species richness and abundance were found to increase in one study where grooves were added along with pits (3473).

For large ridges or ledges (>50 mm), one study reported an increase in the diversity of species and overall abundance of macroalgae, microalgae, and invertebrates (3465). These larger features also increased the abundance of certain species like mussels or limpets, but not barnacles (3465). They did not, however, increase the abundance of juvenile salmon, although they did increase their feeding activity around the structure (3465).

question_details.query: Which habitat creation methods appear most consistently effective at increasing overall species richness on subtidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One of two replicated, randomized, controlled studies found that creating groove habitats and small ledges on a subtidal artificial structure, along with holes and environmentally-sensitive material, increased the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and diversity on structure surfaces (3452). The other study found that creating grooves and small protrusions did not increase the species diversity but had mixed effects on species richness, depending on the orientation of structure surfaces (3452). One study found that creating grooves and small protrusions had mixed effects on the community composition, depending on the orientation of structure surfaces (3452). One study in the Mediterranean Sea recorded at least 53 invertebrate species having colonised a sunken oil rig after 30 years (2262).

question_details.query: What is the evidence for enhancing biodiversity on subtidal artificial structures by creating crevices, protrusions, ridges, ledges, or by reducing their slope?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Three studies investigated the effects of creating grooves and small protrusions, ridges, or ledges (1–50 mm) on subtidal artificial structures. One of these studies, a replicated, randomized, controlled study, revealed that these features, in conjunction with holes and environmentally-sensitive materials, altered the macroalgae and invertebrate community composition, increased species richness and diversity, and supported non-mobile invertebrate species absent from unmodified surfaces (3452). Another study with a similar design reported mixed effects on community composition and species richness depending on the orientation of the structure's surfaces, with no increase in species diversity (3452). This same study also found mixed effects on the abundance of macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrates (3452). A third replicated study reported that grooves and small protrusions were colonized by macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrates (3452). One replicated, randomized, controlled study in Italy that focused on creating natural rocky reef topography on subtidal artificial structures found no increase in the abundance of juvenile canopy macroalgae (3446). There were no studies found that evaluated the effects of creating large ridges or ledges (>50 mm) or reducing the slope of subtidal artificial structures on biodiversity (3445, 3442).

question_details.query: Which habitat creation methods are most consistently effective at altering the overall community composition on intertidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One study in Australia found that creating short flexible habitats (1-50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures altered the community composition of macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrates, but had mixed effects on mobile invertebrates and fish (3459). Another study in the Netherlands reported that creating long flexible habitats (>50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures altered the community composition of macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrates (3460). The habitats also supported macroalgae, mobile and non-mobile invertebrates that were not present on structure surfaces without the flexible habitats (3460). For groove habitats (1-50 mm), two of three studies in Australia and the UK found that they did not alter the macroalgae and invertebrate community composition, while one study did find that they altered community composition (3473). However, one of these studies noted that grooves supported species of macroalgae, mobile and non-mobile invertebrates that were absent from surfaces without grooves (3473). A study in Singapore found that creating groove habitats along with pits altered the fish community composition and supported species absent from surfaces without these features (3473).

question_details.query: What are the potential negative impacts or limitations of adding topographical complexity to enhance biodiversity on intertidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One replicated, randomized, controlled study in Australia found that creating short flexible habitats on intertidal artificial structures decreased the combined macroalgae, invertebrate and fish species richness on and around structure surfaces during low tide (3459). One study found that creating pit habitats on intertidal artificial structures decreased the combined macroalgae and invertebrate abundance on structure surfaces (3475). Another study in the UK found that creating natural rocky reef topography on intertidal artificial structures did not increase the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness on structure surfaces (3435). Other studies found that creating pit habitats did not increase species richness (3475), and creating short flexible habitats did not increase fish species richness or the combined mobile invertebrate and fish abundance (3459). The creation of pit habitats has been found to have mixed effects on the abundance of invertebrates and the overall community composition (3475). Similarly, creating natural rocky reef topography was found to have mixed effects on barnacle and mobile invertebrate abundances (3435). Adding short, flexible habitats also had mixed effects on invertebrate and fish community composition, mobile invertebrate species richness, and the abundance of macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrates (3459).

question_details.query: Besides choosing different construction materials, what other interventions can modify the surface of artificial structures to benefit biodiversity?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One study in southeast Australia found that creating short flexible habitats (1–50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures altered the community composition of macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrates, but had mixed effects on mobile invertebrates and fish during low tide (3459). The same study found that this intervention decreased the overall species richness of macroalgae, invertebrates and fish during low tide (3459). One study in an estuary in southeast Australia reported that reducing the slope of an intertidal artificial structure, in conjunction with creating rock pools, led to an increase in the combined species richness of macroalgae, invertebrates and fish (3461). However, another study in the same region found that reducing the slope alone did not increase the abundance of macroalgae, oysters, or mobile invertebrates (3461). There were no studies found that evaluated the effects of creating large ridges or ledges (>50 mm) on subtidal artificial structures on the biodiversity of those structures (3445).
